title: T4 Troubleshooting Guide
purpose: Provide technicians with a comprehensive procedure to isolate faults and diagnose problems with the T4 manipulator, covering preliminary checks, joint diagnostics, key and freeze button failures, system error messages, status LEDs, voltage test points and factory assistance guidance.
safety: Ensure power is supplied to the master controller, slave arm and servo controller before attempting any diagnostics.
Check that all telemetry conductors are secure at both the slave and master controller connectors.
Do not move joints to their full travel limits while servo loops are open; use the Freeze button to prevent uncontrolled movement.
Do not disable error checking unless instructed by engineering; running with error checking disabled may cause equipment damage.

steps.title: Preliminary Fault Isolation Procedures
text: Ensure that the workstation is receiving electrical power and that the master controller display is on.
Ensure the slave controller is receiving electrical power and the slave arm and servo controller are powered.
Check that the servo commands/resolver inputs at the junction box are connected to the correct vehicle functions.
Ensure all telemetry conductors between the master controller and slave arm show continuity and are properly connected.
If the malfunction persists, use the following sections and troubleshooting tables to isolate the fault.

steps.title: Definitions of Slave Arm Performance
text: Unresponsive: The arm does not respond to commands.
Sluggish: The arm responds slowly or exhibits jerky operation.
Erratic: Joints move unpredictably in response to commands.
Sagging: A joint droops and should be rigid instead.
Hard over: A joint runs to one extreme of travel and stays there.

steps.title: Diagnosing Master/Slave Joint Problems
text: If uncontrolled operation or servo runaway occurs, press the Freeze button to open the servo loops and lock the arm.
Do not move any joint to its full travel limits while the servo loops are open.
When the servo loops are open the joint will remain at the commanded position and will not re-centre when the command is removed.
When the servo loops are closed the joint will re-centre when stow commands are released.
Use the Stow In/Out test by holding the Stow In button for approximately two seconds, releasing it and observing whether the joint recentres.

steps.title: Using the Master Test Screen
text: Access the MASTER TEST screen via the diagnostic menu; the screen locks the servo loops and disables motion.
Each joint is identified by number and displayed with its position value. A bar indicates the jaw band value (0–255).
Use the arrow keys to select a joint and verify that the indicated position value moves when the master controller is operated.
Pressing the Freeze button opens the servo loops; releasing it closes them.
Use the Keys field to observe which keys are depressed. A ‘1’ indicates the key is pressed; a ‘0’ indicates it is released.

steps.title: Using the Slave Test Screen
text: Access the SLAVE TEST screen to verify resolver outputs and servo commands. The screen displays command and position values for each joint.
Open the servo loops and observe the FRZ field; when FRZ is ON the servo loops are open and joints cannot be moved from the slave controller.
Unfreeze by pressing the Freeze button; the servo loops will close and FRZ will change to OFF.
Select a joint and move the master controller; the Command value should change but the Position value should remain constant with the servos open.
Close the servo loops and repeat; both Command and Position values should change together when the joint moves.

steps.title: Travel Limits
text: Do not drive the joints beyond their travel limits shown in the table.
Values may vary slightly from joint to joint but should remain close to the specified minimum and maximum.

steps.title: Diagnosing Key and Freeze Button Failures
text: Observe the Keys field on the MASTER TEST screen. The field displays characters corresponding to function keys and the Freeze button.
A "0" indicates a key is released and a "1" indicates it is depressed.
Depress one key at a time while observing the Keys field to verify that the corresponding character changes from "0" to "1".
If a character does not change when the key is pressed, the key switch or Freeze button may be faulty and must be repaired or replaced.
If no characters change, the interface cable may be at fault; substitute a spare cable to verify.

steps.title: Troubleshooting Tables
text: Use the following tables to diagnose screen-displayed symptoms, master arm symptoms, slave arm symptoms, and jaw problems.
Each table lists possible causes and recommended remedies for the given symptom.

rows: Check master power switch and fuse

steps.title: System Errors
text: Use the SHOW ERRORS menu to display system errors. Error numbers 01 through 07 may be displayed.
Refer to Table 8 for definitions of system errors and Table 9 for possible causes and remedies.
Do not disable error checking unless instructed; if disabling is required, follow manufacturer guidelines.

tables.title: System Errors (Table 8)
rows: Master range error – master joint range exceeded
Slave range error – slave joint range exceeded
Master voltage error – under or over voltage on master
Slave voltage error – under or over voltage on slave
Fatal telemetry error – shut down system

tables.title: Error Causes and Remedies (Table 9)
rows: Stow master joint back into range
Stow slave joint back into range
Master power supply too high or low
Slave power supply too high or low
Shut down system and call factory support

steps.title: Disabling Error Checking and Fatal Telemetry Errors
text: Do not disable error checking unless specifically directed; disabling error checking allows the system to operate with faults unchecked and can result in damage.
If a fatal telemetry error message appears, turn off power to both manipulator arms immediately.
Diagnose and correct the problem before restarting the system; if errors persist after restarting, contact field support.

tables.title: Fatal Telemetry Errors (Table 10)
rows: Communication lost between master and slave
Check telemetry cables and power; restart system
Check slave power supply and fuses
Check master power supply and fuses
Cycle power; reload software if necessary

steps.title: Status Indicator LEDs (Slave Controller)
text: PWR: Illuminated when +/-16 V power is present on the slave board.
PROC: Illuminated when the slave controller CPU is operating.
VALVE: Illuminated when valve power is on; turns off when a fatal error occurs.
TX: Flashes to indicate data transmission to the master.
RX: Flashes to indicate receipt of valid commands from the master.

steps.title: Status Indicator LEDs (Master Controller)
text: Pwr: Power is present on the master board.
Done: The system CPU startup self-test is complete.
Proc: The master CPU is operating correctly.
TX: Flashes when the master is transmitting data to the slave.
RX: Flashes when valid telemetry data is received from the slave.
Jaw: Indicates the jaw module is installed.
Extra: Reserved for factory use.

steps.title: Master Controller Voltage Test Points
text: Test points on the master board allow measurement of +/-16 V, +12 V, +5 V, +3.3 V, +2.5 V, +1.2 V and ground.
Use a suitable meter and test leads to verify these voltages.
The master controller board contains no user-serviceable parts; contact customer service if any faults are found.

steps.title: Factory Assistance
text: If problems persist after following the troubleshooting procedures, contact the factory for assistance.

Be prepared to describe the fault symptoms, whether the problem is constant or intermittent, environmental and operating conditions at the time the problem occurred, whether the fault appeared suddenly or gradually, whether other manipulator functions are affected, and any other relevant information.
Providing complete information will help the factory engineer diagnose and advise corrective action.

notes: Tables are summarised versions of the troubleshooting tables from the manual and maintain the original wording where possible.
Images referenced in the procedure (Figures 1–6) must be saved into the specified assets folder for proper display in the user interface.
